poem.author: Peter McCarey
poem.text: The trees and their location made a grove Sacred - not to the bugs whose housing schemes Disfigured every leaf. And clearly not To those who ground such cynipids to paste For ink. To them the great trees were gall oaks, As though you were known not by or for your name But by your function in some squalid Unembraceable economy. Except for folk on pavements In sopping sleeping bags, that I have the gall (not mine) to write about.
